title: Orbit Communications Company
text:
Orbit Communications Company was a privately owned <a href="Pay%20TV">Pay TV</a> network, operating in the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a>, <a href="Africa">North Africa</a> and <a href="Asia">Asia</a>. Owned by <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>-based <a href="Mawarid%20Holding">Mawarid Holding</a> (via Digital Media Systems), it was the first fully <a href="Digital%20data">digital</a>, multi-channel, multi-lingual, <a href="pay%20television">pay television</a> service in the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> and <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a> and was also the world's first fully end to end digital TV network. Launched in 1994, it was originally situated in Tor Sapienza, Rome, Italy as the location was considered entirely suitable to build a satellite farm. Orbit employed around 600 employees who were largely a combination of British and Italian staff with several Arabic speaking nations also represented. Orbit broadcast in several languages around the world including <a href="English%20language">English</a>, <a href="Arabic%20language">Arabic</a>, <a href="French%20language">French</a> and <a href="Filipino%20language">Filipino</a>.
Some of Orbit's Arabic channels including Bahrain TV, Al Safwa, Fann, Al Yawm, Cinema 1, Cinema 2, Mousalsalat and Mousalsalat +2 are available throughout North and South America through <a href="myTV%20%28Arabic%29">myTV (Arabic)</a>.
In 2009, the company merged with <a href="Showtime%20Arabia">Showtime Arabia</a> to form <a href="OSN">OSN</a>, which is currently the biggest pay-TV provider in the MENA region.

Orbit ESPN's disappearance.
On 1 April 2008, after being on the air since 1994, <a href="Orbit%20ESPN">Orbit ESPN</a> disappeared from the Orbit lineup. This left Orbit without coverage of the <a href="NCAA">NCAA</a>, <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>, the <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a>, <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>, the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>, <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a>, major golf and tennis tournaments, and the premier action sports franchise in the world, ESPN's <a href="X%20Games">X Games</a>.
<a href="Fox%20Sports%20International">Fox Sports</a> replaced <a href="Orbit%20ESPN">Orbit ESPN</a> on 13 January 2009.
One of the reasons that break the contract with ESPN is the severe financial problems happened at that time, since 1999-2000 the production graph line has been moved down. In 2009, a major delay in paying salaries for orbit employees in Egypt, Lebanon and KSA for more than 4 months.
BBC Arabic Television.
<a href="BBC%20Arabic%20Television">BBC Arabic Television</a> was originally transmitted via Orbit from 1994 until April 21, 1996, when it was taken off air by Orbit after the channel broadcast an episode of the BBC "Panorama" program critical of the Saudi Arabian government. Many of the BBC Arabic Television staff then went to work for <a href="Al%20Jazeera">Al Jazeera</a>. The BBC has since relaunched the channel autonomously in 2008.

Showtime Arabia merger.
On 12 July 2009 "<a href="Showtime%20Arabia">Showtime Arabia</a>" and "Orbit Communications Company" announced a merger that created the “biggest Pay-TV platform” in the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> and <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a>.
The newly formed company, which is called OSN, is an equal partnership that would offer 70 exclusive channels featuring new <a href="movies">movies</a>, <a href="sports">sports</a>, <a href="Television%20program">series</a>, <a href="Arabic%20language">Arabic</a> content and international shows.
New customers can subscribe to packages featuring <a href="Showtime%20Arabia">Showtime Arabia's</a> and "Orbit Communications Company"'s programs, while existing subscribers will be able to either retain or upgrade their content. The company will offer <a href="High-definition%20television">HD</a> channels, <a href="video%20on%20demand">video on demand</a> and other <a href="Interactive%20television">interactive</a> services.
